abstract.p: Gives information on the climate around the Falkland Islands and directs Wood to write to Captain Sulivan.

div.p: I received your note of the 5th. only yesterday: I presume the Porter did not forward it to me, as I generally attend the council of the Geolog. Soc. every fortnight, but did not last meeting owing to being unwell. I am sorry to say that I can give you scarcely any information on the points you require; the distance between the two Ports must be at least 30 sea miles, & with the frequent westerly winds difficult to get regularly from Port William to Port Louis. There is moreover a nasty point to touble in going either way in rough weather; & one boat went through to have been in immense daner then.— Nevertheless on an indented coast & with the winds generally more or less off shore I should think the difficulty for long together would seldom be great in passing from one to the other place. The climate is very stormy, but from the Beagle being there twice during only March, I believe we overrated the badness of the climate.— I am positively assured of good authority that the climate is dry & Patagonian durin gsummer; but considering the immense quantity of Peat & the general quantity of the vegetation (like that on a Scotch Mountain) there is almost more than I can believe.—

I presume you cannot wait long for information, otherwise I shd strongly advise you to write to Captn Sulivan (through Capt Beaufort) as I think he knows more of the Falklands than any other person He is very clever & enquiring & now on the spot.. An appearance of levity & great powers of “talk” (for conersation wd be too complimentary) have caused him to be underrated, even, I think by FitzRoy.— I fear the latter will have a place trying to any man’s patience & temper.
I wish I had it in my power to give you better information on this or any other point— & pray believe | sincerely yours | Charles Darwin
